title: In the Drops: Bivo × Velocio × 1% FTP recyclable steel bottle, Restrap tool pouch, Rapha × Brain Dead hip pack and sunshine
content:
Cyclist
In the Drops: Bivo × Velocio × 1% FTP recyclable steel bottle, Restrap tool pouch, Rapha × Brain Dead hip pack and sunshine

It’s Holy Week, and it’s Holy Week, so really Good Friday should be renamed Really Good Friday as it’s also Paris-Roubaix eve and In the Drops day. Crikey, aren’t we lucky?

Obviously, to mark the best week on the pro cycling calendar we’ve been very busy dissecting the Tour of Flanders through Robyn’s Pro Log update, a gallery of highlights from Ashley and Jered Gruber, and my over-excitement about Tadej Pogačar, aka, the GOAT.

We then turned our attention to the Hell of the North with Johan Museeuw’s preview, how to watch the race on TV and in person, and a four-part look at where Paris-Roubaix will be decided.

Tech sleeps for no one, though (which means tech writer Charlotte Head doesn’t sleep either) and Classified announced it’s branching out into MTB, Trek released its very smart new Émonda ALR, and Charlotte rounded up a load of exciting new kit from Road Bike Connection Spring.

We also confirmed Cannondale for our 2023 Track Days, so you can try the brand new SuperSix EVO (and there’s £10 off with code EASTER).

Finally, the great Pippa York joined Emma and Robyn on the Cyclist Magazine Podcast to discuss racing, her transition and being happy.

Let’s play Countdown.

Bivo × Velocio × 1% For the Planet recyclable stainless steel water bottle

Cycling has a plastic problem. Plastic water bottles are everywhere and their main users toss them away on TV every day. Alright, pro bottles go to fans or get swept up most of the time but the point stands. It would be easy to say, ‘Okay, let’s just change to reusable bottles’, but the ease of use of plastic bidons is hard to get away from. Bivo’s One water bottle solves these problems.

The stainless steel the bottle is made from is 100% recyclable and it has been designed by NASA engineers to have a liquid flow similar to plastic cycling bottles. It manages this through an interior straw that lets air into the bottle when you tilt it to help push water out the nozzle and into your mouth without the need to squeeze (because obviously you can’t due to the material).

This special edition of the One – which is also normally available to buy in different colours with an anti-slip silicone exterior – has been made in collaboration with environmentally-conscious clothing company Velocio and 1% For the Planet, a non-profit who will receive all the proceeds from sales of these bottles.

On top of that, Bivo also says that all its bottles are offset to be completely carbon neutral.

  • Buy now from Velocio (£28)

Restrap Tool Pouch

Fresh from the brains of the hottest hands in Yorkshire, this is the newest product from Restrap and it’s a purist’s delight. Fitting in as the smallest product in the Leeds’ manufacturer’s saddle bag range, the Tool Pouch is meant for just carrying those essentials you can forget about until you need them: tools, tubes (I know) and any other small bits you can think of to fit in the 600ml capacity interior.

It’s made with hard-wearing textured nylon that should withstand everything road and off-road rides can throw at it, with a foam cushioning on the inside to protect your stuff and an internal sleeve to keep the smallest items from getting lost at the bottom.

Secured with an adjustable Velcro flap, it can be filled to the brim without being in danger of spillage. As you can see above, it happily holds a can of tomato soup.

  • Buy now from Restrap (£32.99)

Rapha × Brain Dead Trail hip pack

This round-up hasn’t been nearly gnarly enough, so I thought I’d top it off with this trendy hip pack, waist pack, whatever you want to call it from Rapha and clothing brand Brain Dead. My colleague James brought you the hoodie a few weeks ago and this brings even more colour and much more functionality to proceedings.

In contrast to the tool pouch, this has bags of space (pun very much intended), 3 litres to be precise. With two stretchy external mesh pouches that can fit bottles on either side, an external drawcord that can hold the jacket on top, and a small zip pocket for valuables on the front as well, as the main big zipped compartment, it’s an impressive package.

You can wear it round the waist or over the shoulder and it has breathable cushioning and adjustable straps to make sure it’s cosy, secure and doesn’t cause too many sweat-mark issues. It’s made with ripstop nylon so it’s built to take a beating and it just looks cool, doesn’t it? Super gnar, man.

  • RRP: £80/$97/€90
  • Buy now from END. (£79)

Related Posts

2023 bike highlights: Walkable gravel shoes, custom squish saddles, clever bar tape and a Komoot update

Cyclist Magazine Podcast episode 76: Polka dot jersey winner Pippa York on finding happiness

Paris-Roubaix 2023: Routes, start lists and all you need to know

What we’re into this week: Sunshine and Playlist #12

I’m bored of the rain, so consider this my version of a sun dance. The sun just came out as I wrote that, therefore I’m calling that a success. It’s spring now, I know, April Showers and all that, but can it just be dry for a bit? Thanks.

After the great success of playlist’s 1-11, the overlords decided number 12 was a fantastic idea, so I’ve been gathering my favourite new songs since my last In the Drops in February.

This edition has some absolute bangers. ‘Pretty White Dress’ by Alexander Benjamin is a bop and your best bet for saying you got there early as it’s only got 45,000 plays on Spotify with his other three songs having only about 6,000 altogether. ‘Just To Keep You Satisfied’ by Inhaler, fronted by Bono Junior Elijah Hewson, is an instant classic. Shame’s return with ‘Adderall’ is my favourite release of theirs. There are also new releases from Boygenius, The Japanese House, In the Drops’ fave Freak Slug, my fave Dijon, and a live album from the new era of Black Country, New Road, which is fantasic.

  • Listen to In the Drops #12 on Spotify
  • Check out all my In the Drops playlists

author: Will Strickson | Deputy Website Editor
